Deaf individuals have been shown to have a lower recidivism rate compared to other disability groups. A study published in the Journal of Offender Rehabilitation found that deaf individuals were less likely to reoffend compared to hearing individuals, and that they were more likely to successfully complete their probation and parole. This is likely due to the fact that deaf individuals have a more limited social environment, which can make it easier for them to adjust to new situations and avoid returning to prison.
